SpNote.note: WFCAM observing protocol calls for an hourly standard star MSB to be carried out. In general, this should be your source of all calibrations. Notably, photometry and astrometry but also if you stick to "standard" exposure times you should also use the darks from these. If you vary the exposure time, then you will need to insert your own darks.
SpNote.title: Calibrations

SpNote.note:
These MSBs contain a single telescope pointing. They are usefull if you are basically using one of the WFCAM arrays to image a large object or field that is contained within the coverage of that array and are either disregarding the other arrays or are using them as controll fields or similar.
IMPORTANT: Note that the co-ordinates you specify in the target component are for the centre of the wfcam focal plane. This DOES NOT CORRESPOND TO THE CENTRE OF ANY OF THE ARRAYS.
The centres of the arrays are offset from the centre of the wfcam focal plane by approximately 800 arcseconds in both RA and Dec. See the Target Information Note for more details.
The recipe in these sequences (JITTER) assumes that you will have a seperate flat field. If you wish to self flat, change the recipe name to JITTER_SELF_FLAT
SpNote.title: Single filter "paw print" MSBs

SpNote.note:
IMPORTANT: Note that the co-ordinates you specify in the target component are for the centre of the wfcam focal plane. This DOES NOT CORRESPOND TO THE CENTRE OF ANY OF THE ARRAYS.
The centres of the arrays are offset from the centre of the wfcam focal plane by approximately 795 arcseconds in both RA and Dec. You can put +-795 in the xOff and yOff fields to offset your specified RA./Dec position to the centre of one of the arrays. Camera 3 is recomended as being cosmetically clean; setting xOff= -795 and yOff= -795 will place your specified RA/Dec position close to the centre of camera 3.
SpNote.title: Target information - IMPORTANT

SpNote.note: The recipe in these sequences (JITTER) assumes that you will have a seperate flat field. If you wish to self flat, change the recipe name to JITTER_SELF_FLAT
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s or 10s exposures for J, H, K.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them.
SpNote.title: DARKS

SpNote.note:
This pattern aims to offset an integer number of IR pixels as the image may not be oversampled. Also the offsets are an integer number of AG pixels - otherwise the guider will pull it into an integer number anyway.
This pattern is best suited to the "small" microstepping patterns. This pattern is probably too small to use in self-flat observations. This pattern should allways be able to use fast offsetting.
SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.note: If you wish to change the microstepping, go into the microstep itterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. 2x2 small is a good default. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup. "NONE" does no microstepping.
SpNote.title: MicroSteps

SpNote.note:
IMPORTANT: Note that the co-ordinates you specify in the target component are for the centre of the wfcam focal plane. This DOES NOT CORRESPOND TO THE CENTRE OF ANY OF THE ARRAYS.
The centres of the arrays are offset from the centre of the wfcam focal plane by approximately 795 arcseconds in both RA and Dec. You can put +-795 in the xOff and yOff fields to offset your specified RA./Dec position to the centre of one of the arrays. Camera 3 is recomended as being cosmetically clean; setting xOff= -795 and yOff= -795 will place your specified RA/Dec position close to the centre of camera 3.
SpNote.title: Target information - IMPORTANT

SpNote.note: The recipe in these sequences (JITTER) assumes that you will have a seperate flat field. If you wish to self flat, change the recipe name to JITTER_SELF_FLAT
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s or 10s exposures for J, H, K.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them.
SpNote.title: DARKS

SpNote.note:
This pattern aims to offset an integer number of IR pixels as the image may not be oversampled. Also the offsets are an integer number of AG pixels - otherwise the guider will pull it into an integer number anyway.
This pattern is best suited to the "small" microstepping patterns. This pattern is probably too small to use in self-flat observations. This pattern should allways be able to use fast offsetting.
SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.note: If you wish to use microstepping, go into the microstep itterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. 2x2 small is a good default. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup.

SpNote.note:
IMPORTANT: Note that the co-ordinates you specify in the target component are for the centre of the wfcam focal plane. This DOES NOT CORRESPOND TO THE CENTRE OF ANY OF THE ARRAYS.
The centres of the arrays are offset from the centre of the wfcam focal plane by approximately 795 arcseconds in both RA and Dec. You can put +-795 in the xOff and yOff fields to offset your specified RA./Dec position to the centre of one of the arrays. Camera 3 is recomended as being cosmetically clean; setting xOff= -795 and yOff= -795 will place your specified RA/Dec position close to the centre of camera 3.
SpNote.title: Target information - IMPORTANT

SpNote.note: The recipe in these sequences (JITTER) assumes that you will have a seperate flat field. If you wish to self flat, change the recipe name to JITTER_SELF_FLAT
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s or 10s exposures for J, H, K.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them.
SpNote.title: DARKS

SpNote.note:
This pattern aims to offset an integer number of IR pixels as the image may not be oversampled. Also the offsets are an integer number of AG pixels - otherwise the guider will pull it into an integer number anyway.
In this pattern, the seperation betwen the "corner" positions is approx 20 arcsec. This pattern is best suited to the "small" microstepping patterns. This pattern should allways be able to use fast offsetting.
SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.note: If you wish to use microstepping, go into the microstep itterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. 2x2 small is a good default. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup.
SpNote.title: MicroSteps

SpNote.note:
This MSB contains a survey container for doing a single complete tile. You need to add the RA and Dec of your tile centre into *all* *four* target positions in the survey container. the xOff and yOff offsets will offset from there to the 4 pointings for the tile.
This MSB does a 5 point 3.2 arcsec jitter. You can replace the Observation in this MSB with the one from any of the "Survey MSBs" in the WFCAM template library if you require a different pattern.
SpNote.title: Single Tile MSB

SpMSB.title: single tile using 5 point 3.2 arcsec jitter

SpNote.note: The recipe in these sequences (JITTER) assumes that you will have a seperate flat field. If you wish to self flat, change the recipe name to JITTER_SELF_FLAT
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s or 10s exposures for J, H, K.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them.
SpNote.title: DARKS

SpNote.note:
This pattern aims to offset an integer number of IR pixels as the image may not be oversampled. Also the offsets are an integer number of AG pixels - otherwise the guider will pull it into an integer number anyway.
This pattern is best suited to the "small" microstepping patterns. This pattern is probably too small to use in self-flat observations. This pattern should allways be able to use fast offsetting.

SpNote.note: If you wish to use microstepping, go into the microstep itterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. 2x2 small is a good default. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup.
SpNote.title: MicroSteps

SpNote.note:
These MSBs can be used as input to the SDT for carrying out surveys. You can also fill in the list of pointings in the survey container by hand.
Note. If you want to survey a small area in several filters, create seperate MSBs for each filter, or at least seperate observations in a seperate survey container - if you put a filter itterator inside the observation in these MSBs you will incur huge overheads from filter changes, each of which takes ~30 secs.
SpNote.title: Survey MSBs

SpNote.note: The recipe in these sequences (JITTER) assumes that you will have a seperate flat field. If you wish to self flat, change the recipe name to JITTER_SELF_FLAT

SpNote.title: Narrow band imaging

SpNote.note:
IMPORTANT: Note that the co-ordinates you specify in the target component are for the centre of the wfcam focal plane. This DOES NOT CORRESPOND TO THE CENTRE OF ANY OF THE ARRAYS.
The centres of the arrays are offset from the centre of the wfcam focal plane by approximately 795 arcseconds in both RA and Dec. You can put +-795 in the xOff and yOff fields to offset your specified RA./Dec position to the centre of one of the arrays. Camera 3 is recomended as being cosmetically clean; setting xOff= -795 and yOff= -795 will place your specified RA/Dec position close to the centre of camera 3.

SpNote.title: MicroSteps

SpNote.note:
Please contact your support scientist well in advance if you are planning to use any of these MSBs!!!
There are two flavours of sky observations with flipping between cameras, named FAST and SLOW. In the FAST flavour, we move to the first jitter position, perform a full 2x2 microstep sequence, move to the sky, and then repeat the microstep. Graphically: - jitter 0 - microstep on target - microstep on sky - jitter 1 - microstep on target - microstep on sky and so on...
In the SLOW flavour, a full jitter + microstep sequence is performed before moving to sky. - jitter 0 - microstep on target - jitter 1 - microstep on target ... - jitter 5 - microstep on target - jitter 0 - microstep on sky - jitter 1 - microstep on sky ...
Please note that Target and Sky only indicate the two pointings required to flip the target between cameras 1 and 2. Target is the pointing that puts the object on camera 1, while Sky is the pointing that puts the object in camera 2. None of them is a real "empty" sky. Also note that we have included filter changes and flushes, since most likely these MSBs will be used for bright objects.
The two MSBs called M83 show an example of a complete MSB with a target component and a 3 filter survey.
SpNote.title: Flipping between cameras with sky eye

SpNote.note:
This observation should flip a target between camera's 1 and 2 so that alternate frames can be used for sky-subtraction. Note that the "Observes" should be with the target in camera 1, while the "Skies" should be with the target in camera 2.
It executes a 2x2 microstep sequence at every stop in the jitter pattern with the target in camera 1 before switching to camera 2.
How to prepare the Target Component: 1- enter the coordinates of the center of your main target 2- note that the offsets (+765 +765) will automatically move it to camera 1 3- change the xOff to -765 4- click on Add Sky (lower left). This will add the correct sky position that will put your target on camera 2 5- click again on "Base" in the list of target, so that it is highlighted 6- Revert back the xOff to +765
At this point you have the two positions, and all you need to do is to add guide stars. Using Plot, start the position editor and add a guide star for your Base position. Adding a guide star to your sky position requires a little more work. In the position editor, click on the button "Catalogs" Scroll down to your favourite image server (DSS at CADC is a good choice). The coordinates are already correct, but you will have to change the size of the image to 60x40. This will give you enough coverage to see the sky position and the surrounding stars. Click on the SKYGUIDE button on the left, and click on a suitable guide star for your sky position. Note that you will NOT see the autoguider outline around your sky position. You will have to guess if you guide star is close enough to the sky0 position to be useful. Still, the autoguider outline will be displayed around the main position, as a visual aid.
SpNote.title: What this observation does

SpNote.note: In the Target component below, the BASE should put the target in camera 1. The SKY should then put the target in camera 2. NOTE: Use a dummy MSB to get the coords for the SKY and the SKYGUIDE.
SpNote.title: What to put in the target component

SpNote.note: JITTER is the default DR recipe used by the WFCAM pipeline in cambridge. It is the ONLY recipe that will work, although a new recipe for sky subtraction is being developed.
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s or 10s exposures for J, H, K.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them. See WFCAM web pages for details.
SpNote.title: DARKS

SpNote.note: This offset/microstep pattern below results in the microstep pattermn being done just once at each "observe" or "sky" position, i.e. one microstep sequence with the target in camera 1 or camera 3. A second or third offset could be added to each offset, though only use 3.2 or 6.4 arcsecs to be assured of fast offsetting.
SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.note: If you wish to change the microstepping, go into the microstep itterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. 2x2 small is a good default. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup.
SpNote.title: MicroSteps

SpNote.note: In the Target component below, the BASE should put the target in camera 1. The SKY should then put the target in camera 2. NOTE: Use a dummy MSB to get the coords for the SKY and the SKYGUIDE.
SpNote.title: What to put in the target component

SpNote.note: JITTER is the default DR recipe used by the WFCAM pipeline in cambridge. It is the ONLY recipe that will work, although a new recipe for sky subtraction is being developed.
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s or 10s exposures for J, H, K.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them. See WFCAM web pages for details.
SpNote.title: DARKS

SpNote.note: This offset/microstep pattern below results in the microstep pattermn being done just once at each "observe" or "sky" position, i.e. one microstep sequence with the target in camera 1 or camera 3. A second or third offset could be added to each offset, though only use 3.2 or 6.4 arcsecs to be assured of fast offsetting.
SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.note: If you wish to change the microstepping, go into the microstep itterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. 2x2 small is a good default. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup.

SpNote.note: This offset/microstep pattern below results in the microstep pattermn being done just once at each "observe" or "sky" position, i.e. one microstep sequence with the target in camera 1 or camera 3. SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.title: MicroSteps

SpNote.note:
This observation should flip a target between camera's 1 and 2 so that alternate frames can be used for sky-subtraction. Note that the "Observes" should be with the target in camera 1, while the "Skies" should be with the target in camera 2.
It executes a 2x2 microstep sequence AND a 5-point jitter pattern with the target in camera 1 before switching to camera 2 and repeating the 5x2x2=20 exposures. It is therefore more efficient than FLIP_FAST though it switches between cameras (and therefore samples sky) less frequently.
How to prepare the Target Component: 1- enter the coordinates of the center of your main target 2- note that the offsets (+765 +765) will automatically move it to camera 1 3- change the xOff to -765 4- click on Add Sky (lower left). This will add the correct sky position that will put your target on camera 2 5- click again on "Base" in the list of target, so that it is highlighted 6- Revert back the xOff to +765
At this point you have the two positions, and all you need to do is to add guide stars. Using Plot, start the position editor and add a guide star for your Base position. Adding a guide star to your sky position requires a little more work. In the position editor, click on the button "Catalogs" Scroll down to your favourite image server (DSS at CADC is a good choice). The coordinates are already correct, but you will have to change the size of the image to 60x40. This will give you enough coverage to see the sky position and the surrounding stars. Click on the SKYGUIDE button on the left, and click on a suitable guide star for your sky position. Note that you will NOT see the autoguider outline around your sky position. You will have to guess if you guide star is close enough to the sky0 position to be useful. Still, the autoguider outline will be displayed around the main position, as a visual aid.
SpNote.title: What this observation does

SpNote.note: In the Target component below, the BASE should put the target in camera 1. The SKY should then put the target in camera 2. NOTE: Use a dummy MSB to get the coords for the SKY and the SKYGUIDE.
SpNote.title: What to put in the target component

SpNote.note: JITTER is the default DR recipe used by the WFCAM pipeline in cambridge. It is the ONLY recipe that will work, although a new recipe for sky subtraction is being developed.
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s or 10s exposures for J, H, K.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them. See WFCAM web pages for details.
SpNote.title: DARKS

SpNote.note:
This pattern aims to offset an integer number of IR pixels as the image may not be oversampled. Also the offsets are an integer number of AG pixels - otherwise the guider will pull it into an integer number anyway.
This pattern is best suited to the "small" microstepping patterns. This pattern is probably too small to use in self-flat observations. This pattern should allways be able to use fast offsetting.
SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.note: If you wish to alter the microstepping pattern, go into the microstep iterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup.
SpNote.title: MicroSteps

SpNote.note: In the Target component below, the BASE should put the target in camera 1. The SKY should then put the target in camera 2. NOTE: Use a dummy MSB to get the coords for the SKY and the SKYGUIDE.
SpNote.title: What to put in the target component

SpNote.note: JITTER is the default DR recipe used by the WFCAM pipeline in cambridge. It is the ONLY recipe that will work, although a new recipe for sky subtraction is being developed.
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s or 10s exposures for J, H, K.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them. See WFCAM web pages for details.
SpNote.title: DARKS

SpNote.note:
This pattern aims to offset an integer number of IR pixels as the image may not be oversampled. Also the offsets are an integer number of AG pixels - otherwise the guider will pull it into an integer number anyway.
This pattern is best suited to the "small" microstepping patterns. This pattern is probably too small to use in self-flat observations. This pattern should allways be able to use fast offsetting.
SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.note: If you wish to alter the microstepping pattern, go into the microstep iterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup.
SpNote.title: MicroSteps

SpNote.note: In the Target component below, the BASE should put the target in camera 1. The SKY should then put the target in camera 2. NOTE: Use a dummy MSB to get the coords for the SKY and the SKYGUIDE.
SpNote.title: What to put in the target component

SpNote.note: JITTER is the default DR recipe used by the WFCAM pipeline in cambridge. It is the ONLY recipe that will work, although a new recipe for sky subtraction is being developed.
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s or 10s exposures for J, H, K.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them. See WFCAM web pages for details.
SpNote.title: DARKS

SpNote.note:
This pattern aims to offset an integer number of IR pixels as the image may not be oversampled. Also the offsets are an integer number of AG pixels - otherwise the guider will pull it into an integer number anyway.
This pattern is best suited to the "small" microstepping patterns. This pattern is probably too small to use in self-flat observations. This pattern should allways be able to use fast offsetting.
SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.note: If you wish to alter the microstepping pattern, go into the microstep iterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup.
SpNote.title: MicroSteps

SpNote.note:
This observation should flip a target between camera's 1 and 2 so that alternate frames can be used for sky-subtraction. Note that the "Observes" should be with the target in camera 1, while the "Skies" should be with the target in camera 2.
It executes a 2x2 microstep sequence AND a 5-point jitter pattern with the target in camera 1 before switching to camera 2 and repeating the 5x2x2=20 exposures. It is therefore more efficient than FLIP_FAST though it switches between cameras (and therefore samples sky) less frequently.
The target NGC4526 demonstrates what should happen - display this target in the position edotor, then edit the coords and put in your own target.
SpNote.title: What this observation does

SpNote.note: In the Target component below, the BASE should put the target in camera 1. The SKY should then put the target in camera 2. NOTE: Use a dummy MSB to get the coords for the SKY and the SKYGUIDE.
SpNote.title: What to put in the target component

SpNote.note: JITTER is the default DR recipe used by the WFCAM pipeline in cambridge. It is the ONLY recipe that will work, although a new recipe for sky subtraction is being developed.
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s or 10s exposures for J, H, K.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them. See WFCAM web pages for details.
SpNote.title: DARKS

SpNote.note: This offset/microstep pattern below results in the microstep pattermn being done just once at each "observe" or "sky" position, i.e. one microstep sequence with the target in camera 1 or camera 3. A second or third offset could be added to each offset, though only use 3.2 or 6.4 arcsecs to be assured of fast offsetting.
SpNote.title: Offset Pattern

SpNote.note: If you wish to change the microstepping, go into the microstep itterator below and select the pattern you wish to use. 2x2 small is a good default. The different "NxN small" patterns do the microstepping in different orders, to avoid persistant image buildup.
SpNote.title: MicroSteps

SpNote.note: In the Target component below, the BASE should put the target in camera 1. The SKY should then put the target in camera 2. NOTE: Use a dummy MSB to get the coords for the SKY and the SKYGUIDE.
SpNote.title: What to put in the target component

SpNote.note: JITTER is the default DR recipe used by the WFCAM pipeline in cambridge. It is the ONLY recipe that will work, although a new recipe for sky subtraction is being developed.
SpNote.title: DRrecipe

SpNote.note:
Set filters and exposure times etc in the WFCAM component.
In general, we advocate sticking to 5s or 10s exposures for J, H, K.
SpNote.title: WFCAM component

SpNote.note: If you are using a "non standard" exposure time, you will need to insert some darks here. I recomend adding 3 to 5 darks if you need them. See WFCAM web pages for details.
